Award.AwardTitle: Scholars Award: Calculating the American Way: Computing Productivity in Transatlantic Relations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This project investigates transatlantic transfers of US productivity technology and culture from the 1920s to the 1960s with a focus on their adaption in Germany. To better understand the role of US capitalism in transatlantic relations, it examines how productivity shaped the labor-management relations that characterize modern industrialized nations. The results of this research will eventually be published in a book that will provide an historical perspective to questions concerning economic competitiveness. It will promote a deeper understanding of the historical, cultural, and political roots of the liberal and social economic systems on either side of the Atlantic, and it will assess their relative strengths and weaknesses. The results will serve to shed light on current issues, such as how labor standards around the globe affect national competitiveness. The PI will present the results of her research at academic conferences, and she will seek to contribute to a better public understanding of the role of science and technology in transatlantic relations through public lectures as a Speaker in the Humanities program of the New York Council for the Humanities, and through the placement of op-ed articles in the local and national press.

Technical Summary

The focus of this project is located at the intersection of science and technology studies and the histories of computing, business and foreign relations. As such, it is well positioned to examine the modes of circulation of productivity ideas and technologies across the Atlantic, from the individual endeavors before WWII to the government-mediated programs after the war. Doing so will contribute to a better understanding of why, despite increasing globalization, heterogeneity persists among western industrialized countries. It will contribute to a new chronology of the histories of computing and technology by integrating the decades before and after WWII; instead of assuming that World War II was a watershed moment, this project traces political, cultural and technical continuities and changes from the prewar to the postwar period. The project will also link together a diversity of actors including government officers, corporate executives and engineers, labor advisors and trade union delegates on both sides of the Atlantic. In doing so, it will reveal a complex web of public and private diplomacy, and it will provide new insights into how the circulation of productivity technology shaped mutual perceptions of social and industrial relations on either side of the Atlantic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Corinna Schlombs analyzed how Germans appropriated American productivity technologies and culture between the 1920s and the 1960s with a focus on Ford?s mass production and electronic computing technologies.

Productivity is defined as the statistical measure of output per man hour. But key findings from this project showed that productivity has interpretive flexibility, that is different groups view productivity differently, and their views have changed over time. Also, productivity was emblematic of the US economic system, became instrumental in efforts to reshape the German economy after the US model, and played an important role in the US rise to global dominance.

The research shows that the meaning of productivity and its social and economic values changed over time. In the 1920s, officers of the US Bureau of Labor Statistics developed productivity indexes to analyze economic and labor changes resulting from technological improvement in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. After World War II, the Marshall Plan?s Productivity Program became a vehicle to reshape European economies after the US model. In the emerging Cold War, the promise of higher standards of living for all due to higher productivity was to counter communist promises of a better life from a communal economy, and productivity came to mean more than increased worker output through technological improvement. To scholars of science and technology, the research shows that the inscription of values into productivity technologies did not end once the technologies were created; their values continued to be negotiated as the technologies moved across the Atlantic. Recognizing that technologies carry social constructed values allows scholars in related fields such as economics to critically interrogate them and understand how they guide economic and political practices, rather than taking them for granted.

The research also shows that American expectations of economic growth and higher standards of living through increasing productivity from technological improvements were unique to the American economic model. They mark important differences between the US and European economies that persisted despite intense transatlantic interactions, and even despite American efforts at reshaping European social and economic relations after the US model. Before WWII, individual American businessmen, such as Henry Ford, communicated ideas about labor and economic relations to audiences abroad, and Weimar Germans and other Europeans eagerly studied the production technologies behind the US economic prowess. After WWII, the Marshall Plan administration?with support by US corporations and labor unions?undertook a concerted effort through its Productivity Program to reshape class and labor relations in Western Europe. The research revealed continuing transatlantic differences between capitalist economies even during the height of the Cold War, casting a new light on the notion of the ?West? for historians of foreign relations. The research has revealed the details of why and how capitalist countries have different conceptions of economic growth, disclosing historical contingency in what could be seen as temporal directionality to scholars of capitalism. It contributes to explanations why different varieties of capitalism existed, and persist.

To complete the project, Schlombs conducted research in four archives in the United States and Germany, analyzed the archival sources, and composed a book manuscript.

The primary outcome of this award is a scholarly monograph, Productivity Machines: German Appropriations of American Technologies from Mass Production to Computer Automation which was published by MIT Press in 2019. The book has already found the attention of political economists concerned about decreasing productivity rates in OECD countries.

Additional outcomes include two peer-reviewed articles in scholarly journals, a chapter for an edited volume for a broader technically interested audience, and fifteen presentations to professional and broader educated audiences.

Broader impacts of this project include a companion website to the book that makes key archival sources available for research and teaching purpose (www.productivitymachines.com), and a newly developed advanced undergraduate course on technology in US foreign relations, HIST 383 Technology and Global Relations in the American Century. Both provided training and professional development opportunities for students at Rochester Institute of Technology.
